answers.answer: The cause of your labored breathing, along with “a constant tightness in my chest”, must be determined and treated without delay.  The most common causes of labored breathing during pregnancy would include asthma and pulmonary emboli (clots to the lung).  Each is a serious disease, very serious if not recognized and treated and can threaten the well-being of both mother and fetus.  Another possibility is that you might have previously unrecognized pulmonary hypertension or congenital heart disease.  And, finally, there is an equally dangerous condition associated with pregnancy that can also harm both mother and infant called, The Antiphospholipid Syndrome.*  (see belowWhat I am saying is that the onset of shortness of breath during pregnancy, presumably above and beyond the shortness of breath resultant from an enlarging uterus impinging on the diaphragms, should be treated as a serious symptom.From your description, it appears that your doctors do not attribute your respiratory symptoms to a serious disease.  You have two choices:  1) depending on the trust you have in your doctors, you might ask one of them to pursue this matter comprehensively, without delay or, 2) express your concern, cite this message if you like and request consultation with a lung specialist (pulmonologist) promptly.  Promptly, because there is no time to waste.  Whatever your decision, make it now, do not be the least concerned about hurting anyone’s feelings, and do whatever you have to do to get assistanceGood luck to you and your baby.  Please let us know how things go.*Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome and Pregnancy•	Author: Teresa G Berg, MD, FACOG; Chief Editor: Carl V Smith, MD   more...BackgroundRecognized for its associated thrombosis in the 1950s, antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) and lupus anticoagulant (LAC) are associated with pregnancy complications that include fetal loss, fetal growth restriction, preeclampsia, thrombosis, and autoimmune thrombocytopenia. It is characterized by an autoimmune process that is separate in many women from systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other connective tissue diseases. Diagnosis requires clinical and laboratory findings with the clinical criteria being the primary method of diagnosis. Women with the clinical features should be tested for LAC and anticardiolipin (aCL) antibodies; most patients with APS have both LAC and aCL immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies.APS is classified as primary or secondary depending on its association with other autoimmune disorders. Primary antiphospholipid syndrome is diagnosed in patients demonstrating the clinical and laboratory criteria without other recognized autoimmune disease. Secondaryantiphospholipid syndrome is diagnosed in patients with other autoimmune disorders such as SLE.Antiphospholipid (aPL) antibodies belong to the large family of antibodies that react with negatively charged phospholipids (PLs) including cardiolipin, phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylinositol, phosphatidylserine, phosphatidylcholine, and phosphatidic acid.LAC and aCL predispose to clotting in vivo, predominantly by interfering with the antithrombotic role of PLs; thus, it is associated with clinical thrombosis, not bleeding. The aPL autoantibodies bind moieties on negatively charged PLs or moieties formed by the interaction of negatively charged PLs with other lipids, PLs, or proteins.

question: Hello I have been to my doctors nearly 10 times in the past month due to not being able to breathe 24/7. I have a constant tightness in my chest and it gets worse at night. All the doctors have done is offer me a nasal spray and then some tablets which didnt do anything! I'm pregnant and constantly out of breathe and struggling to breathe. What else can I do?
title: Bad asthma in pregnancy
